title: How to Format Any Computer: PC, Mac, & Chromebook

steps.title: Back up your data.
steps.content: Back up your data. Although formatting your Windows 10 or 11 PC is super easy, the changes are permanent—you'll be deleting all of your apps, settings, and personal files and reinstalling Windows from scratch. You can back up your files to an external hard drive, or a cloud storage service like Google Drive , or OneDrive . [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Open your Windows Settings .
steps.content: Open your Windows Settings . To do so, click the Windows Start menu and then click the gear icon. If you can't boot into Windows, you can boot into Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE). To do so, power your computer on and immediately press and hold the Power button to shut it down as soon as you see the startup logo. Repeat three times to boot into WinRE. Once you boot into WinRE, select Troubleshoot and Reset this PC .

steps.title: Click System or Update & Security.
steps.content: Click System or Update & Security . If you are using Windows 11, click System in the menu bar to the left. If you are using Windows 10, click the Update & Security icon. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Recovery.
steps.content: Click Recovery . On Windows 11, it's about three-quarters of the way down the System menu. On Windows 10, it's in the menu panel on the left. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Reset PC or Get started.
steps.content: Click Reset PC or Get started . If you are using Windows 11, click Reset PC next to "Reset this PC." If you are using Windows 10, click Get Started below "Reset this PC." [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Remove everything.
steps.content: Click Remove everything . It's the second option on the blue screen. This option will completely erase your hard drive and remove all your files. Baron explains that you can't erase the C drive when you're booted into Windows, as Windows is currently running on the drive. Because of this, Windows will reboot your computer before it erases the data on your C drive. Clearing the drive is important if you're planning to sell or give away this PC. That's because formatting the hard drive makes it hard for someone malicious to restore your deleted files. But if you want to keep the PC, you can click Just remove my files to skip formatting the drive. Another more serious option for cleaning the hard drive is to use a third-party data-wiping tool like DBAN (Darik's Boot and Nuke). If you use a drive-clearing program, you'll need to make sure you have a Windows recovery drive or DVD so you can reinstall the operating system. See How to Clean a Hard Drive to learn more about this option.

steps.title: Click Cloud Reinstall.
steps.content: Click Cloud Reinstall . This option will download the latest version of Windows from the internet and provide a clean installation. If you do not have an internet connection, you can click Local reinstall to reinstall Windows using a local installation file from your computer. This option tends to be quicker.

steps.title: Click Next on the warning screens.
steps.content: Click Next on the warning screens. You will get one or two warning screens: The first informs you that all your files will be removed and Windows will be reinstalled, and the second explains that you will revert to a previous Windows version and lose updates. Click Next on both screens. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Click Reset to format your PC.
steps.content: Click Reset to format your PC. Depending on the size and speed of your hard drive, this part can take a while (anywhere from several minutes to several hours). [6] X Research source If you're using a laptop, make sure you plug it into a power source so the formatting is not interrupted.

steps.title: Click Continue when the format is complete.
steps.content: Click Continue when the format is complete. Your PC is now formatted. If you'd like to reinstall Windows , follow the on-screen instructions to do so. Baron notes that you'll be asked where you want to install Windows during the installation process. If you want to do a clean install, delete all the partitions shown until it's all unallocated space. Then, click Next , and Windows will automatically create new partitions for you.

steps.title: Back up your data.
steps.content: Back up your data. Formatting your Mac will erase all your data, so ensure you've backed up everything you want to keep. See How to Back Up a Mac to learn how to save your files to Time Machine or iCloud. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings. To do so, click the Apple icon in the menu bar at the top and select System Settings (or System Preferences on earlier macOS versions). This method works for Macs that have an Apple T2 or Apple Silicon chip running macOS Monterey or later. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Click General.
steps.content: Click General . If you are using macOS Ventura or later, click General in the menu bar to the left.

steps.title: Click Transfer or Reset.
steps.content: Click Transfer or Reset .

steps.title: Click Erase All Content and Settings and enter your administrative password.
steps.content: Click Erase All Content and Settings and enter your administrative password. Type your password to log in to your Mac, then click Unlock or OK . This will open the reset assistant.

steps.title: Click Continue.
steps.content: Click Continue . The reset assistant displays all the content that will be erased by resetting your Mac. Review the information and click Continue in the lower-right corner. If prompted, sign out of your Apple ID.

steps.title: Click Erase All Content & Settings.
steps.content: Click Erase All Content & Settings . The pop-up window gives you a final warning that this can't be undone. Click Erase All Content & Settings to continue. If you are selling your Mac, you can stop once your Mac reboots to the setup process.

steps.title: Follow the prompts to set up your Mac like new.
steps.content: Follow the prompts to set up your Mac like new. When your Mac finishes restarting, you will be prompted to connect your keyboard and mouse again via Bluetooth (if needed). You may also be prompted to connect to Wi-Fi to activate your Mac. Once you're finished, click Restart to set up your Mac like new.

steps.title: Back up all your data.
steps.content: Back up all your data. Formatting your Chromebook will erase all data you have saved on your device. Back up everything you want to keep. You can back up your files to Google Drive and sync your settings with your Google account.

steps.title: Sign out of your Chromebook.
steps.content: Sign out of your Chromebook. You'll first want to sign out of your Google account on your Chromebook: Click the time in the lower-right corner. Click the Power icon. Click Sign Out .

steps.title: Press and hold Ctrl+Alt+⇧ Shift+R.
steps.content: Press and hold Ctrl + Alt + ⇧ Shift + R . This will open the Reset menu. Alternatively, you can click the time, select the gear icon, and go to System preferences > Reset . If prompted, click Restart to continue.

steps.title: Click Powerwash.
steps.content: Click Powerwash . It's the lower-right corner. You will see a pop-up warning alerting you that this will erase all data on your computer.

steps.title: Click Continue.
steps.content: Click Continue . This will format your Chromebook and erase all data and settings. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Back up your data.
steps.content: Back up your data. Formatting your Mac will erase all your data, so ensure you've backed up everything you want to keep. See How to Back Up a Mac to learn how to save your files to Time Machine or iCloud. [10] X Research source This method works for older Macs that have Intel processors.

steps.title: Restart your Mac and press ⌘ Command+R.
steps.content: Restart your Mac and press ⌘ Command + R . If your Mac is already turned on, reboot it and press this key combination as soon as it turns back on. This boots your Mac into Recovery Mode. [11] X Research source You can release your fingers from the keys once you see the Apple logo or a startup screen.

steps.title: Select Disk Utility.
steps.content: Select Disk Utility . It's the last option on the "macOS Utilities" window. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Click Continue.
steps.content: Click Continue . It's at the bottom-right corner.

steps.title: Click the View menu.
steps.content: Click the View menu. It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Show All Devices.
steps.content: Click Show All Devices . This displays all disks connected to your Mac in the left panel. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Select the disk you want to format.
steps.content: Select the disk you want to format. For example, if you want to format the primary drive on which macOS is installed, you'll select the first disk at the top of the list (under "Internal"). In most cases, this will be called "Macintosh HD."

steps.title: Click the Erase button.
steps.content: Click the Erase button. It's near the top-center part of the window.

steps.title: Select your formatting details.
steps.content: Select your formatting details. [14] X Research source Name: Enter a name to identify the hard drive. Format: Unless you have a specific reason not to do so, leave the default format of your internal hard drive as APFS . [15] X Research source Scheme : Select Choose GUID Partition Map .

steps.title: Click Erase to format the disk.
steps.content: Click Erase to format the disk. You may be asked to verify your Apple ID or password. Once the disk is erased and formatted, you'll return to the Disk Utility list. [16] X Research source If you have additional hard drives, you can format them now using Disk Utility.

steps.title: Close Disk Utility.
steps.content: Close Disk Utility. You can do this by clicking the red circle at the top-left corner of the window. If you want to reinstall macOS on this drive, just boot back into Recovery Mode by pressing Control + R at startup, and then select Reinstall macOS (to start from scratch) or Restore From Time Machine Backup (if you backed up the OS to Time Machine).

steps.title: Back up your data.
steps.content: Back up your data. Since formatting your PC will erase all your files and settings, you'll probably want to do a backup first. Check out How to Back Up a Windows Computer to learn how to quickly back up your PC before you proceed. [17] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If your PC came with Windows 8 instead of Windows 8.1, formatting and resetting will revert you to Windows 8. [18] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source But don't worry—you'll be prompted to install a free upgrade to Windows 8.1 soon after installing.

steps.title: Hold the mouse cursor at the bottom-right corner of the screen.
steps.content: Hold the mouse cursor at the bottom-right corner of the screen. This opens the Charms menu.

steps.title: Click Settings .
steps.content: Click Settings . It's the gear icon on the Charms menu.

steps.title: Click Change PC Settings.
steps.content: Click Change PC Settings . It's at the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Click the Update and recovery tab.
steps.content: Click the Update and recovery tab. It's near the bottom of the left panel.

steps.title: Click Recovery.
steps.content: Click Recovery . It's on the right panel.

steps.title: Click Get started under "Remove everything and reinstall Windows."
steps.content: Click Get started under "Remove everything and reinstall Windows." It's in the middle of the right panel. Make sure you don't accidentally click "Get started" under a different option, as there are several. [19] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . This confirms that you want to delete your files, apps, and settings from this PC.

steps.title: Select which drive(s) you want to format.
steps.content: Select which drive(s) you want to format. If you only want to format the drive on which Windows 8 is installed, select Only the drive where Windows is installed . To format all drives on the computer, select All drives .

steps.title: Click Fully clean the drive.
steps.content: Click Fully clean the drive . This option (the second one) ensures that the drive is completely formatted. If you plan to keep the PC and aren't worried about people accessing your deleted files, you can click Just remove my files . This won't format the drive, though. A more serious option for cleaning the hard drive is to use a third-party data-wiping tool like DBAN (Darik's Boot and Nuke). DBAN and similar tools make it impossible for anyone to find fragments of your deleted files, so this might be useful if you plan to sell or give away your PC. Just make sure you have recovery media so you can reinstall Windows afterward. See How to Clean a Hard Drive to learn more about this option.

steps.title: Click Reset to format your PC.
steps.content: Click Reset to format your PC. Depending on the size and speed of your hard drive, this part can take a while (anywhere from several minutes to several hours). If you're using a laptop, make sure you plug it into a power source so the formatting is not interrupted. Once the PC is formatted, it will reboot and prompt you to reinstall Windows. Follow the on-screen instructions if you'd like to do so.
